{{Infobox single | Name = To Kill the Child" / "Leaving Beirut | Cover = KillTheChildBeirut.jpg | Artist = [[Roger Waters]] | A-side = "To Kill the Child" | B-side = "Leaving Beirut" | Released = {{Start date|2004}} | Format = [[CD single]], [[music download|digital download]] | Genre = [[Progressive rock]] | Label = [[Columbia Records|Columbia]]
[[Sony Music Japan]] (CD5) | Writer = Roger Waters | Producer = Roger Waters and Nick Griffiths | Last single = "Three Wishes"
(1992) | This single = "'''To Kill the Child'''" / "'''Leaving Beirut'''"
(2004) | Next single = "[[Hello (I Love You)]]"
(2007) }} "'''To Kill the Child'''"/"'''Leaving Beirut'''" is a [[2004 in music|2004]] [[music download|digital download]]{{cite book|last=Manning|first=Toby|title=The Rough Guide to Pink Floyd|year=2006|publisher=Rough Guides|location=London|isbn=1-84353-575-0|page=147|edition=1st|chapter=Which One's Pink?}} and a Japan-only [[CD single]] written and performed by [[Roger Waters]]. =="To Kill the Child"== The first song of the single runs at 3 minutes and 31 seconds. The lyrics open with the image of a child sleeping "in the glow of [a] [[Donald Duck]] light",[http://www.roger-waters.com/lyricschild.html To Kill the Child lyrics] a reference to Waters' prior song "[[The Tide Is Turning]]." Waters goes on to ask why a culture whose primary concerns are [[materialism|luxury]], [[conspicuous consumption|consumption]] and [[dogma|petty values]] would "kill the child". The song ends with a plea to protect children from the crusade-waging "bigots and bully boys / Slugging it out in the yard." =="Leaving Beirut"== The second track of the single runs at 12 minutes and 29 seconds. Most of the song's lyrics are derived from a short story about Waters' [[hitchhiking]] excursion in [[Lebanon]] when he was a teenager. These passages, intoned in monologue over a [[Melodic motion|descending]] [[synthesizer]] [[ostinato]], are interspersed with more recently penned [[refrain]]s outlining Waters' reaction to [[United States]] and [[United Kingdom]] involvement in the [[Iraq War]]. Waters performed the song at every show on his [[The Dark Side of the Moon Live]] tour, replacing the spoken-word recitation with a visual backdrop of the story as a [[graphic novel]]. ===Controversy and criticism=== Waters' condemnation of [[George W. Bush]] (at one point, the song's lyrics claim "that Texas education must have fucked [him] up")[http://www.roger-waters.com/lyricsbeirut.html Leaving Beirut lyrics] received negative reactions from audience members during his show at [[New Jersey]]'s [[PNC Bank Arts Center]] on 6 September 2006, at [[Madison Square Garden]] in [[New York City]] on 12 September 2006 and in [[Tampa, Florida]] on 19 May 2007; however, audience reactions during the 5 October 2006 performance at the [[Hollywood Bowl]] were overwhelmingly positive, with many patrons rising to their feet and cheering. The song also received a positive reaction during its American performances at the [[Boston, Massachusetts]] and [[Camden, New Jersey]] [[Tweeter Center (disambiguation)|Tweeter Center]]s, in New York on 30 May 2007, as well as in other cities worldwide, particularly [[Mumbai]] and [[Dubai]].[http://ian-ritchie.com/rwblog.htm Ian Ritchie's tour blog] Ironically, during his first show in Dallas, Texas on 2 May 2008, the line referring to George Bush and the Texas education was met with uproarious applause. His last show on the American leg of the tour, in [[Houston, Texas|Houston]] on the 4th, was met with a fairly mixed reaction. While many fans have embraced the song's lyrical content, which is sympathetic towards the people of Lebanon, some have objected to Waters' political stance. In 2006, Waters performed a concert in [[Neve Shalom]], [[Israel]] in front of a crowd of 50,000. During the concert, which included "Leaving Beirut" in the set-list, Waters expressed his belief that Israel had to "tear down the walls" of the [[Israeli West Bank barrier]] (pictured in the single's [[cover art]]) to make peace with its neighbours.[http://oasisofpeace.org/press/rogerwaters2.pdf Press release] The morning after Waters' concert in [[Neve Shalom]], editorial writer [[Ben Dror Yemini]] wrote in the [[Israel]] newspaper ''[[Maariv]]'': {{quote|[I]nstead of demonstrating against genocide in Sudan, or arrests in Syria, or the oppression of women in Saudi Arabia, Waters demonstrated against Israel[...] So who made you boss, Mr. Waters? Who are you to preach to us against the separation fence? What do you know about the hundreds of Israelis whose blood was spilled? What do you know about an entire nation that has to protect itself? What do you know about the hundreds of suicide bombers who came here not to kill the occupation, but to kill Jews?{{cite web|url=http://web.israelinsider.com/Views/8732.htm |publisher=''[[Israel Insider]]''|accessdate=2008-06-30|title=Anti-Israel artists: Pink Flawed or Pink Fraud|author=Bedein, David|date=2006-06-23}}}} The song has also received some criticism for its musical content and style; one review of the 10 October show at the [[Shoreline Amphitheater]] in [[Mountain View, California]] claimed that the song "floundered" musically despite being lyrically "one of Waters' best post-[[Pink Floyd|Floyd]] works."[http://www.mercurynews.com/mld/mercurynews/news/columnists/15735054.htm San Jose Mercury News] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Roger Waters}} {{DEFAULTSORT:To Kill The Child Leaving Beirut}} [[Category:2004 singles]] [[Category:Roger Waters songs]] [[Category:Protest songs]] [[Category:Songs critical of religion]] [[Category:Songs of the Iraq War]] [[Category:Songs about cities]] [[Category:Songs about Lebanon]] [[Category:Songs written by Roger Waters]] [[Category:Songs based on actual events]] [[Category:Anti-war songs]] [[Category:2004 songs]] [[Category:Columbia Records singles]]

{{About|the actor|the wrestler who shares the same real name|Tommy Dreamer}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Tom Laughlin | image = Tom Laughlin 1978.jpg | imagesize = | caption = Laughlin in 1978 | birth_name = Thomas Robert Laughlin Jr.<ref name=nyt1>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/12/17/movies/tom-laughlin-82-star-of-billy-jack-movie-series-dies.html|title=Tom Laughlin, 82, Star of ‘Billy Jack’ Movie Series, Dies|first=Paul|last=Vitello|date=December 16, 2013|publisher=|via=NYTimes.com}}</ref> | birth_date = {{birth date|1931|8|10|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2013|12|12|1931|8|10|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Thousand Oaks, California]], U.S. | othername = Tommy Laughlin, T.C. Frank, Don Henderson, Mary Rose Solti, Frank Laughlin, Frank Christina, Lloyd E. James | occupation = Actor, film director, film producer, screenwriter, educator | years_active = 1955–2010 | spouse = {{marriage|[[Delores Taylor]]|1954|2013}} (his death); 3 children | website = {{url|billyjack.com}} }}
'''Thomas Robert Laughlin Jr.''' (August 10, 1931 – December 12, 2013), known as '''Tom Laughlin''', was an American actor, director, screenwriter, author, educator, and activist.
Laughlin was best known for his series of ''[[Billy Jack]]'' films. He was married to actress [[Delores Taylor]] from 1954 until his death. Taylor co-produced and acted in all four ''Billy Jack'' films. His unique promotion of ''[[The Trial of Billy Jack]]'' (TV trailers during national news and an "opening day" nationwide release) was a major influence on the way films are marketed.<ref name="New York Times">{{cite news|last=Maslin|first=Janet|title=Hollywood's Attack of the Monster Releases|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/09/30/books/30masl.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 30, 2004|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref>
In the early 1960s, Laughlin put his film career on hiatus to start a [[Montessori education|Montessori]] preschool in [[Santa Monica, California]]; it became the largest school of its kind in the United States. In his later years, he sought the office of [[President of the United States]] in 1992, 2004, and 2008. He was involved in psychology and domestic abuse counseling, writing several books on [[Analytical psychology|Jungian psychology]] and developing theories on the causes of cancer.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8GJV84ZF-hM|title=Psychology of Cancer - 6 Factors Summarized|first=|last=Tom Laughlin|date=April 30, 2011|publisher=|via=YouTube}}</ref>
==Early life and career (1931–1960)== Laughlin was born in [[Milwaukee]], Wisconsin, the son of Margaret and Thomas Laughlin.<ref name=nyt1/> He attended [[Washington High School (Milwaukee, Wisconsin)|Washington High School]],<ref>{{cite news|last=Skalitzky|first=Lori|title=Real-Life Drama Brings Laughlin Home|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=JmcxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6BIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3429,5352545&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[The Milwaukee Sentinel]]|date=October 10, 1986|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Borsuk|first=Alan J.|title=Washington High Alumni stroll down Memory Lane |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=NmYaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=dyoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6417,3406758&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[The Milwaukee Journal]]|date=October 21, 1991|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> where he was involved in an athletics controversy that made headlines throughout the city, caused by Laughlin being forced to attend another school for a brief period, making him ineligible to play football at his former school on his return.<ref>{{cite news|last=Letwin|first=Bill|title=School Board Approves New Setup for Athletics|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=L_UZAAAAIBAJ&sjid=yiMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5371,4801015&dq=tom+laughlin+ineligible&hl=en|work=[[The Milwaukee Journal]]|date=June 6, 1949|accessdate=February 19, 2010}} {{Failed verification|date=April 2010}}</ref>
Laughlin attended the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison|University of Wisconsin]], before transferring to [[Marquette University]]; he played football at both.<ref name="sptimes.com">{{cite news|last=Montgomery|first=Ben|title=Is it Time for Billy Jack to Come Back?|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2007/08/19/news_pf/Features/Is_it_time_for_Billy_.shtml|work=The St. Petersburg Times|date=August 19, 2007|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> He played [[Safety (American and Canadian football position)|safety]] and [[halfback (American football)|halfback]] at Marquette.<ref>{{cite news|last=DeLong|first=Jack|title=Marquette Coach Seeks to Replace Injured Regulars|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=5zgoAAAAIBAJ&sjid=FCQEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6706,4588480&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[Milwaukee Journal]]|date=October 25, 1950|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref>
Laughlin decided to become an actor after seeing a production of ''[[A Streetcar Named Desire (play)|A Streetcar Named Desire]]''.<ref name="time.com">{{cite journal|title=The Two Faces of Tom|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,913555-1,00.html|journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date=October 6, 1975|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> According to a 1956 newspaper interview, he became involved in the drama program at Marquette after being encouraged by a university professor, Father John J. Walsh.<ref name="Actin">{{cite news|last=Spiro|first=J.D.|title=Milwaukee's Actin' Tom Laughlin |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eTEaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=5iUEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5732,2727998&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[Milwaukee Journal]]|date=August 26, 1956|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref>
While a student he formed a stock group and directed and starred in a production of [[Arthur Miller]]'s ''[[All My Sons]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Stock Group will Play on Saturday|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=yAUkAAAAIBAJ&sjid=axAEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5648,3744754&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[Milwaukee Sentinel]]|date=August 8, 1952|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> He finally transferred to the [[University of South Dakota]], where he majored in radio acting, directing and producing.<ref name="Actin"/> He met his future wife [[Delores Taylor]] in South Dakota.
Laughlin wrote the original screenplay for the film ''[[Billy Jack]]'' in 1954, after witnessing the treatment of [[Native Americans in the United States|Native Americans]] in his wife's hometown, [[Winner, South Dakota]].<ref>Casuso, Jorge ''The Legend of Billy Jack'', Billy Jack Enterprises, 1999</ref><ref name="Sacramento">{{cite journal|title=Interview with Tom Laughlin|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YFPk6-RjtOc&feature=video_response|journal=Good Morning Sacramento (KMAX)|date=January 22, 2001|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> The two wed on October 15, 1954.<ref name="Actin"/>
He began his screen-acting career in the 1955 television series ''[[Climax!]]''.<ref name="Actin"/> From there he went on to appear in several feature films including: ''These Wilder Years,'' ''[[Lafayette Escadrille (film)|Lafayette Escadrille]]'', ''[[Tea and Sympathy (film)|Tea and Sympathy]]''<ref name="Actin"/> and ''[[South Pacific (1958 film)|South Pacific]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Winchell|first= Walter|title=Walter Winchell's Broadway Beat|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=6QUdAAAAIBAJ&sjid=2IoEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7316,536404&dq=tom+laughlin+walter+winchell&hl=en|work=The Sarasota Journal|date=August 8, 1952|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref>
He appeared in several episodes of various television series throughout the late 1950s. In 1958, Mr. Laughlin appeared in a small but memorable role in South Pacific, the movie version of the James Michener book and Rodgers and Hammerstein musical as a Navy pilot, Lt. Buzz Adams. In 1959, he was cast as young Tom Fowler in the episode "The Fight Back" of the [[NBC]] [[Western (genre)|western]] series, ''[[Riverboat (TV series)|Riverboat]]''. In the story line, Fowler has made himself the boss of Hampton, a corrupt river town near [[Vicksburg, Mississippi]]. He blocks farmers from shipping their crops to market. In a dispute over a wedding held on the river vessel, the ''Enterprise'', a lynch mob led by Fowler comes after Captain Grey Holden (series star [[Darren McGavin]]). Also appearing in this episode are [[John Ireland (actor)|John Ireland]] as Chris Slade and [[Karl Swenson]] as Ansel Torgin.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0687109 |title="The Fight Back", ''Riverboat'', October 18, 1959|publisher=[[Internet Movie Data Base]]|accessdate=February 27, 2013}}</ref>
In 1959, Laughlin appeared in the film ''[[Gidget (film)|Gidget]]'' as "Lover Boy". However, he failed to earn a living in the early years, having told ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine in 1975, "We were living on $5 a week and eating [[Spam (food)|Spam]]. I stole Christmas cards from a church so I could write home saying how well we were, but then I couldn't afford the stamps."<ref name="people.com">{{cite journal|last=Wilkins|first=Barbara|title=It's Been a Cruel World for Tom Laughlin, but can Billy Jack Save It?|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20065776,00.html|journal=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=October 20, 1975|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref>
Laughlin's first starring role was in [[Robert Altman]]'s 1957 film ''[[The Delinquents (1957 film)|The Delinquents]]'', in which he played Scotty White, a teenager who gets mixed up with a gang when he is told he can no longer see his girlfriend.<ref name="Actin"/> Despite the film's low budget, it became a cult film, with [[Alfred Hitchcock]] reportedly among its fans.<ref>{{cite news| last=Burr|first=Ty|title=Hollywood Outsider Finally Receives his Due|url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/living/articles/2006/03/05/hollywood_outsider_finally_receives_his_due|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=March 5, 2006|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> However, Laughlin and Altman did not get along well,<ref name="Stafford">{{cite web|last=Stafford|first=Jeff|title=Cult Movies Showcase: The Delinquents|url=http://www.tcm.com/thismonth/article/?cid=87816&rss=mrqe|work=[[Turner Classic Movies]]|publisher=TCM.com|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> having sharply differing views on acting; Altman later describing Laughlin as "an unbelievable pain in the ass."<ref name="Stafford"/>
Laughlin made his directorial debut later that year with ''[[The Proper Time]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Overview for ''The Proper Time'' (1960)|url=http://www.tcm.com/tcmdb/title.jsp?stid=499605|work=[[Turner Classic Movies]]|publisher=TCM.com|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> though the film wasn't released until 1960. The film was a romantic drama set on the campus of [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]]. Laughlin shot the film on the campus in six days<ref>{{cite news|last=Holley|first=Jannelle|title=Collegiate Drama Joins Hotter-than-Ever Trends|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EiUsAAAAIBAJ&sjid=S54FAAAAIBAJ&pg=799,6353071&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=The Florence Times Daily|date=December 23, 1959|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=McDonald|first=Thomas|title=Film Man with a Dream and 'The Proper Time'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1960/01/17/archives/film-man-with-a-dream-and-the-proper-time.html| work=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 17, 1960|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> working with a $20,000 budget.<ref>{{cite news|last=Bennett|first=Jerry|title= Democrat Ladies 'Insulted'|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=FmscAAAAIBAJ&sjid=404EAAAAIBAJ&pg=7424,688806&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[The Pittsburgh Press]]|date=December 3, 1960|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref>
Laughlin wrote, directed, and starred in ''[[The Young Sinner (1965 film)|The Young Sinner]]''. Originally filmed in 1960, and shot in Milwaukee over a period of 14 days,<ref>{{cite news |last=Means|first=Marianne|title=Movie 'Shooting' Set Here Monday|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=n2YcAAAAIBAJ&sjid=z04EAAAAIBAJ&pg=5733,527358&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[Milwaukee Sentinel]]|date=August 11, 1960|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> it is the story of a star high school athlete who falls deeper and deeper into trouble after being caught in bed with his girlfriend. The film was intended to be the first of a trilogy entitled ''We Are All Christ''.<ref>{{cite book|last=Krasfur|first=Richard P.|title=The American Film Institute Catalog of Films Produced in the United States 1961–1970|page=1259|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=s1k1RsGvFwwC&pg=PA1259|publisher=University of California Press|year=1997|isbn=978-0-520-20970-1 |accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> It premiered in 1963 under the original title ''Among the Thorns'',<ref>{{cite news|last=Bach|first=Erwin|title= U of C to Offer Film Prizes|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/581453562.html?dids=581453562:581453562&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Mar+14,+1963&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=U.+of+C.+Will+Offer+Film+Prizes&pqatl=google|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=March 14, 1963|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> which was changed to ''The Young Sinner'' upon its 1965 re-release.<ref>{{cite news|last=Meyer|first=Kathleen|date=May 27, 1990|title=You Asked.....|work=Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=MWSB&p_theme=mwsb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB8260F280FC170&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> In 1960, Laughlin planned to make a film, ''Poison in Our Land'', based on the true story of a Texas couple affected by atomic radiation, but the project was never realized.<ref>{{cite news|last=Parsons |first=Louella|title=Hard to Scare|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wykxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=7A8EAAAAIBAJ&pg=7202,1653408&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[Milwaukee Sentinel]]|date=May 3, 1960|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref>
==Leaving Hollywood (1961–1966)== In 1959, Laughlin and his wife founded a [[Montessori education|Montessori]] preschool in [[Santa Monica, California]].<ref name="sptimes.com"/> By 1961, Laughlin had left the film business to devote all of his time to the school, which by 1964 had become the largest school of its kind in the United States. It was profiled by ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine in July of that year.<ref>{{cite journal|last=|first=|title=Teaching: Montessori in the Slums| url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,871265,00.html|journal=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|volume=84|issue=2|date=July 10, 1964 |accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> However, by 1965, the school had gone bankrupt.<ref name="people.com"/> One of his students was [[Christian Brando]], son of Laughlin's friend, [[Marlon Brando]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Kunen|first=James|title=Brando's Son Faces Murder Charge| url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20117861,00.html|volume= 33|issue=22|journal=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=June 4, 1990 |accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref>
==Billy Jack years (1967–1977)== In 1965, Laughlin told the ''[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|Milwaukee Sentinel]]'' that he planned to make a film on the life of a noted Catholic priest, Father [[William DuBay]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Herzog|first=Buck|title=Laughlin Plans Second Film|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2MMVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=QREEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7050,60616&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[Milwaukee Sentinel]]|date=July 1, 1965|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> However, the picture did not get past the planning stages. Two years later, in 1967, he wrote, directed (as T. C. Frank) and starred in the motorcycle-gang exploitation film ''[[The Born Losers]]''.<ref>{{cite news|last=Pepan|first=Bea J.|title=Producers 'on Location' for Holiday in Wisconsin|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=BVcaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9ycEAAAAIBAJ&pg=7074,6069612&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[Milwaukee Journal]]|date=August 20, 1967|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> This was the first picture in which the character of Billy Jack appeared. It was a box-office hit.<ref>{{cite web|last=Smith|first=Richard Harland|title=Biker Classics: The Born Losers|url=http://www.tcm.com/thismonth/article.jsp?cid=161084&mainArticleId=220876|work=[[Turner Classic Movies]]|publisher=TCM.com|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=B6700 Born Losers (1967)|url=http://www.lasalle.edu/library/vietnam/FilmIndex/Assets/B6700_BORN_LOSERS.pdf|journal=[[La Salle University]]|accessdate=February 20, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100528090214/http://www.lasalle.edu/library/vietnam/FilmIndex/Assets/B6700_BORN_LOSERS.pdf|archivedate=May 28, 2010}}</ref>
After ''The Born Losers,'' Laughlin was set to begin a film project with backing from such figures as [[Marlon Brando]], [[Jack Lemmon]], [[Candice Bergen]], and director [[Robert Wise]]. The movie was to be a documentary on the issues facing African Americans in the 1960s and would have focused greatly on the life of [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]] followed by a discussion of race.<ref>{{cite news|last=Thomas|first=Bob|title=Group to Produce Film about Plight of the Negro|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=M2UpAAAAIBAJ&sjid=f8kEAAAAIBAJ&pg=815,4703611&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=Daytona Beach Morning Journal|date=June 20, 1968|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> However, the film was never made.
He followed this up with the sequel to ''The Born Losers,'' ''[[Billy Jack]],'' in 1971. [[American International Pictures]] initially agreed to distribute the picture but after viewing it the studio refused to release the film unless many of the political references – as well as frontal nudity – were cut. This led the Laughlins to withhold the sound reels of the movie, which in effect made it a silent film.<ref name="time.com"/><ref>{{cite book|last=Christina|first=Frank and Teresa|title=Billy Jack|publisher=Avon Books|year=1973|page=Introduction}}</ref><ref name="Laughlin1">{{cite journal|last=Laughlin|first=Tom|title=Warners Destroys Billy Jack Negative |url=http://billyjack.com/warners/990927.html |date=September 27, 1999 |accessdate=February 20, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991012052924/http://billyjack.com/warners/990927.html |archivedate=October 12, 1999}}</ref> Eventually, Laughlin made a distribution deal with [[Warner Bros.]] but he disapproved of the studio's marketing of the film, sued Warners, and re-released the picture himself.<ref name="sptimes.com"/> The movie's re-release was successful but controversial. [[Roger Ebert]], in his review of the film, wrote, "Billy Jack seems to be saying that a gun is better than a constitution in the enforcement of justice. Is democracy totally obsolete, then? Is our only hope that the good fascists defeat the bad fascists?"<ref>{{cite news|last=Ebert|first=Roger|title=Billy Jack |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19710802/REVIEWS/101010302/1023|work=[[The Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=August 2, 1971|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref>
However, the picture was embraced by much of America's youth,{{Citation needed|date=December 2013}} leading Laughlin to claim in 1975 that "The youth of this country have only two heroes, [[Ralph Nader]] and Billy Jack."<ref name="time.com"/> When adjusted for inflation, it is, as of 2007, the highest-grossing [[independent film]] of all time.<ref name="Sacramento"/> The film was among the first to introduce martial arts, especially [[hapkido]] to American audiences and contained elements of [[Analytical psychology|Jungian psychology]], and fictional depictions of American Indian beliefs, depicting a tribe that does not exist, the "Nishnobie."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Forbes|first=David|title=An Interview with Bong Soo Han|url=http://www.martialinfo.com/article.asp?gbfspn=493|journal=Traditional Tae Kwon-Do|date=Fall 1975|accessdate=February 20, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090314014229/http://www.martialinfo.com/article.asp?gbfspn=493|archivedate=March 14, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref> As part of the film's promotion, [[Han Bong-soo|Bong Soo Han]], who was in charge of the martial arts choreography for the film,<ref>{{cite news|title=Bong Soo Han, 73, Orchestrator of Martial Arts Scenes|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B03E1DF1030F937A25752C0A9619C8B63|work=[[The New York Times]] |date=January 14, 2007|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> toured the United States giving hapkido demonstrations.<ref>{{cite news|last=Noth |first=Dominique Paul |title=Karate Expert on Chop Chop Tour, with Hollywood Footing the Bill|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xSchAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gCgEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5263,615577&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[Milwaukee Journal]]|date=May 22, 1971|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref>
The second sequel, ''[[The Trial of Billy Jack]]'', released in late 1974, was a huge box office hit, while not registering as quite as big a critical success.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Trial of Billy Jack - Box office Gross|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/1974/0TBJK.php|publisher=The-numbers.com |accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> It is notable for its casting of Native American icons such as [[Sacheen Littlefeather]] and [[Rolling Thunder (person)|Rolling Thunder]], as well as its strong criticism of the [[Kent State shootings]].<ref name="Sacramento"/> However, Laughlin's unique promotion of the film was its real legacy. Unlike most films of the era which opened in only a few cities before gradually spreading across the country, ''The Trial of Billy Jack'' opened in cities nationwide on the same day and commercials were broadcast for it during the national news. This promotion forever changed the way films are marketed and has been called "the first [[blockbuster (entertainment)|blockbuster]]."<ref name="New York Times"/><ref>{{cite news|last=Gibron |first=Bill|title=Billy Jack, the Original Blockbuster|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/column/billy-jack-the-original-blockbuster|work=[[PopMatters]] |date=June 5, 2007|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref>
In 1975, Laughlin released ''[[The Master Gunfighter]]'', a western set in the 1840s, detailing the plight of the [[Chumash people]]. Laughlin grew a full beard for the film and his character fought with both a 12-shot revolver and a [[Katana|samurai sword]].<ref name="people.com"/> Although it did reasonably well at the box office, critics were not pleased with the film.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ebert|first=Roger|title=The Master Gunfighter |url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19750101/REVIEWS/501010342/102|work=[[The Chicago Sun-Times]]|date=January 1, 1975|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref>
He returned to the Billy Jack franchise in 1977. However, the fourth entry in the series, ''[[Billy Jack Goes to Washington]]'' was a failure because of distribution problems,<ref name="Laughlin1"/> and it proved to be Laughlin's final film . Laughlin blamed individuals within the United States government for the failure of the picture, telling [[CNN]]'s ''[[Showbiz Tonight]]'' in 2005:<blockquote>At a private screening, Senator [[Vance Hartke]] [Note: Hartke was not re-elected in 1976] got up, because it was about how the Senate was bought out by the nuclear industry. He got up and charged me. [[Walter Cronkite]]'s daughter was there, [and] [[Lucille Ball]]. And he said, 'You'll never get this released. This house you have, everything will be destroyed.' "<ref name="transcripts.cnn.com">{{cite web|title=Showbiz Tonight (transcript) |url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/0510/27/sbt.01.html|work=[[CNN]]|date= September 27, 2005|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref></blockquote>
At the time of the picture's release, Laughlin's company, Billy Jack Enterprises, had plans for a new Montessori school funded by his own foundation, a record label, an investigative magazine, books, a distribution company and more message-laden movies, including a special subsidiary to produce films for children.<ref>{{cite news|last=Scott |first=Vernon |title=Laughlin: He Did it His Way |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=KTIMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UF8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5760,2090406&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en |work=St. Petersburg Times |date=November 27, 1975 |accessdate=February 19, 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref> He told ''People'' magazine at the time, "Three years from today, we'll be the new [[United Artists]]. Either that, or we'll be out on our butt on the street."<ref name="people.com"/> In 1976, Laughlin announced that he was more than $7 million in debt and blamed the financial troubles on unethical behavior by Warner Bros. Pictures, which he said had illegally sold the television rights to his films.
==Later career== In 1984, he purchased a series of twelve advertisements in ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' condemning various aspects of the film industry and its treatment of independent filmmakers. He created a blueprint for taking control of the home video distribution industry as a way for independent films to be seen.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Rhodes |first=Lucien|title=The Return of Billy Jack|url=http://www.inc.com/magazine/19871201/4594.html|journal=Inc. Magazine|date=December 1, 1987 |accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> This plan was also a failure. In 1985, he began production of a fifth Billy Jack film, ''[[The Return of Billy Jack]]'',<ref>{{cite news |title=Return of Billy Jack (1986)|work=The New York Times|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/135276/Return-of-Billy-Jack/overview}}</ref> which featured the title character fighting child pornographers in New York City. However, he suffered a concussion and neck injury during filming, which led to the production being suspended. During this hiatus, funding for the picture ran out and production was never resumed.<ref>{{cite news|title=Actor Hurt During Filming|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=9LQRAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6OkDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5876,2111360&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=The Gainesville Sun|date=February 7, 1986|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> In 2009, a few scenes from the unfinished film were released on Laughlin's website. A notable incident occurred while he was filming in New York City, when he broke up a street fight on Manhattan's West Side, threatening to rip a man's arm off.<ref>{{cite news|last=United Press International|title=Life Imitates Art: Billy Jack Saves Downtrodden—From Further Abuse|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/24933358.html?dids=24933358:24933358&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+28,+1986&author=United+Press+International&pub=Chicago+Tribune+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=LIFE+IMITATES+ART:+BILLY+JACK+SAVES+DOWNTRODDEN--FROM+FURTHER+ABUSE&pqatl=google|work=The Chicago Tribune|date=August 28, 1986|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> He garnered notoriety at this time for making a [[citizen's arrest]] of a man after an argument over Laughlin's driving.<ref>{{cite news|title=Billy Jack Character Lives, Makes Arrest|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wUQlAAAAIBAJ&sjid=ZagFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3479,2723047&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=The Montreal Gazette|date=May 5, 1986|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref>
Laughlin had sought funding to finish the fifth Billy Jack film since at least 1996, when he spoke about it during a lawsuit against a man who had (Laughlin claimed) illegally changed his name to "Billy Jack",<ref>{{cite news|last=Cave|first=Kathy|title=Check the Sign, Mister |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=LnAaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6i0EAAAAIBAJ&pg=5963,3517514&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel|date=May 3, 1996|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> and at one point Laughlin had plans to make a Billy Jack television series.<ref>{{cite web|last=Laughlin|first=Tom|title=New Film/New Studio|url=http://billyjack.com/info_pages/newstudio.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19991013074819/http://billyjack.com/info_pages/newstudio.html|archivedate=October 13, 1999}}</ref> In 2004, he announced that the film would be entitled ''Billy Jack's Crusade to End the War in Iraq and Restore America to Its Moral Purpose''; this was shortened to ''Billy Jack's Moral Revolution'' in 2006.{{citation needed|date=June 2018}}
In 2008, the film's title was changed to ''Billy Jack for President''.<ref name="sptimes.com"/> It was re-titled ''Billy Jack and Jean''. Laughlin claimed it would be a "new genre of film" and a great deal of social commentary on politics, religion, and psychology will be discussed,<ref>{{cite news|last=Waxman|first=Sharon|title=Billy Jack is Ready to Fight the Good Fight Again|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/06/20/movies/20jack.html?pagewanted=print|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=June 20, 2005|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> and a debate will take place between Billy Jack and [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]] via computer manipulation of archived speeches.<ref name="transcripts.cnn.com"/>
In 2009, Laughlin released plot details of this film on a video on his website. The video contained several scenes from the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=219|title=New Billy Jack Film: Billy Jack and Jean|last=Laughlin|first=Tom|year=2009|accessdate=March 2, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726163900/http://www.billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=219|archivedate=July 26, 2011}}</ref>
In 2010, Frank, Chris, and Theresa Laughlin co-founded '''Billy Jack Rights, LLC''', which manages the rights to all of Tom Laughlin's films, including the ''Billy Jack'' franchise.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.billyjackrights.com/how-we-came-to-own-billy-jack|title=Billy Jack Rights, LLC: "How We Came to Own ‘Billy Jack’"|last=Laughlin|first=Frank|year=2010|accessdate=August 30, 2012}}</ref>
==Other work== ===Politics=== In his later years, Laughlin turned his attention to politics. In 1992, as a protest<ref name="Sacramento"/> he sought the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] nomination for U.S. President.<ref name="sptimes.com"/> He told the ''Milwaukee Sentinel'', "I am the least qualified person I know to be President, except George Bush."<ref>{{cite news|title=Laughlin Hates Politics, May Run|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=oG0WAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9RIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6204,2625492&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[The Milwaukee Sentinel]]|date=September 12, 1991|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref>
He appeared on the primary ballots in [[United States presidential election in New Hampshire, 1992|New Hampshire]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ourcampaigns.com/RaceDetail.html?RaceID=36387|title=New Hampshire – U.S. President- D. Primary|publisher=Ourcampaigns.com |accessdate=March 2, 2010}}</ref> and [[Louisiana]]. He campaigned on a platform of a [[tax cut]] for "ordinary Americans", [[term limit]]s, an overhaul of [[State school|public education]], [[universal health care]], and [[nuclear disarmament]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Primaries: Who Needs Cuomo?|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,974634,00.html|journal=Time|date=January 13, 1992|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Laughlin|first=Tom|title=Two Americas|url=http://billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=58|journal=campaign literature|year=1991|accessdate=February 20, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726154852/http://billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=58|archivedate=July 26, 2011}}</ref> While campaigning for the [[Iowa caucuses|Iowa caucus]], he said of fellow candidate and Iowan, [[U.S. Senator]] [[Tom Harkin]]: "I think he's a sleazebag. I despise him."<ref>{{cite news|last=Associated Press|title=Tough Talk from Laughlin|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-V4rAAAAIBAJ&sjid=6tkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4875,7204715&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=Iowa Daily Reporter|date=November 27, 1991|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref>
Excluded from debates by party officials who did not consider him a serious candidate, Laughlin received 1,986 votes in the [[New Hampshire primary]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=Eugene J. McCarthy Papers|url=http://special.lib.umn.edu/rare/mccarthy.phtml|journal=University of Minnesota|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Associated Press|title='Billy Jack' Laughlin gets 1% of N.H. Vote|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=MWSB&p_theme=mwsb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB826F4AECE3538&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|work=[[The Milwaukee Sentinel]]|date=February 19, 1992|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> He blamed the results on lack of cooperation by the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]], which allowed him and other candidates only five minutes to speak at the state's convention while giving the five front-runners 20 minutes each. He participated in the Independent presidential candidates Debate on March 25, 1992, along with former U.S. Senator [[Eugene J. McCarthy]] and others who had been excluded from the major debates.<ref>{{cite web|title=Independent Presidential Candidates Debate|url=http://www.c-spanarchives.org/library/index.php?main_page=product_video_info&products_id=25190-1|work=[[C-SPAN]]|date=March 25, 1992|accessdate=February 20, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930160034/http://www.c-spanarchives.org/library/index.php?main_page=product_video_info&products_id=25190-1|archivedate=September 30, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref> However, he was seen by much of the press as a "fringe candidate."<ref>{{cite news|last=Baer|first=Susan|title=From 'Messiah' to 'Billy Jack', Dozens Want Bush's Job |url=http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=19911113&slug=1317049|work=[[The Seattle Times]]|date=November 13, 1991|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Desenport|first=Ellen|title= Fringe Dwellers Seek the White House|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=DRgMAAAAIBAJ&sjid=elwDAAAAIBAJ&pg=2019,3609025&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[The St. Petersburg Times]]|date=November 29, 1991|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref>
Laughlin later protested at being excluded from the primary ballot in his home state of Wisconsin at the same time that [[David Duke]], the former [[Grand Wizard]] of the [[Ku Klux Klan]], was included.<ref>{{cite news|title=What About Billy Jack? State Court has made Travesty of Primary|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=l3sWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=zRIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4976,2215627&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=[[The Milwaukee Sentinel]]|date=March 11, 1992|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> After dropping out of the race, he worked as an advisor to the campaign of [[Ross Perot]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Cheevers|first=Jack|title=Poll of Perot Activists a Charade, Ex-Backers Say Politics: Texan runs the show, they assert, and is not just bowing to volunteers. Billionaire has spent heavily|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/61694147.html?dids=61694147:61694147&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+01,+1992&author=JACK+CHEEVERS;+JOHN+M.+BRODER&pub=Los+Angeles+Times+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Poll+of+Perot+Activists+a+Charade,+Ex-Backers+Say+Politics:+Texan+runs+the+show,+they+assert,+and+is+not+just+bowing+to+volunteers.+Billionaire+has+spent+heavily.&pqatl=google|work=[[The Los Angeles Times]]|date=November 1, 1992|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref>
He ran for president again in 2004,<ref>{{cite web| last=Laughlin|first=Tom|title=Laughlin for President: A Powerful New Voice to Give Real Power Back to All the People|url=http://igoberserk.billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=33|work=billyjack.com|year=2003|accessdate=February 20, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040214022538/http://igoberserk.billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=33|archivedate=February 14, 2004}}</ref> this time as a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]].<ref>{{cite journal|title='Billy Jack' Star Making Political Statement|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-7134806.html|journal=Deseret News|date=February 3, 2004|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> Campaigning as an opponent of the [[Iraq War]], he received 154 votes in the New Hampshire primary against U.S. President [[George W. Bush]].<ref>{{cite web|title=New Hampshire Republican Primaries Results|url=http://www.thegreenpapers.com/P04/NH-R.phtml|work=The Green Papers|date=January 27, 2004|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> He again was not allowed to participate in the debates.<ref>{{cite web|last=Farrell|first=James|title=Gore for Dean, and Debate Night|url=http://www.nhpr.org/node/12877|work=New Hampshire Primary|date=December 9, 2003|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> He ran again for President in 2008<ref>{{cite web|last=Laughlin|first=Tom|title=Laughlin for President Pt. 2- My Plan to End the Iraq War (video)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SPFZZQuXJgc&feature=channel_page|work=billyjack.com|date=November 15, 2007|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> as a Democrat, getting 47 votes in the New Hampshire primary.<ref>{{cite news|last=Montgomery|first=Ben|title=Whatever happened to ... The 1970s Icon with a Conscience?|url=http://www.sptimes.com/2008/01/20/Life/Whatever_happened_to_.shtml|work=St. Petersburg Times|date=January 20, 2008|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref>
Laughlin was an outspoken critic of the Iraq War<ref>{{cite web|last=Laughlin|first=Tom|title=America has Lost its Moral Purpose and character|url=http://billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=38|work=billyjack.com|accessdate=February 20, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726154913/http://billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=38|archivedate=July 26, 2011|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name="Doug Basham">{{cite web|last=Basham |first=Doug|title=Interview with Tom Laughlin (audio)|url=http://www.dougbasham.com/BillyJack.mp3|work=dougbasham.com|date=May 11, 2005|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> and President George W. Bush.<ref>{{cite web|last=Laughlin|first=Tom|title=The Case that George W. Bush is Not the Legally Elected President...the Overwhelming Proof|url=http://www.billyjack.com/politics/excerpt_01.html|work=billyjack.com|date=January 20, 2001|accessdate=February 20, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010304115222/http://www.billyjack.com/politics/excerpt_01.html |archivedate=March 4, 2001}}</ref> His website presented several writings calling the Iraq conflict worse than the [[Vietnam War]], in addition to pieces on what he called "realistic exit strategies."<ref>{{cite web|last=Laughlin|first=Tom|title=New Exit Strategy from Iraq|url=http://www.billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=142|work=billyjack.com|accessdate=February 20, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090122201438/http://www.billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=142|archivedate=January 22, 2009}}</ref> He devoted several pages of the Billy Jack website to reasons that he feels justify an [[impeachment]] of [[George W. Bush]]<ref>{{cite web|last=Laughlin|first=Tom|title=The Power of Impeachment|url=http://www.billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=187|work=billyjack.com|accessdate=February 20, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090122204150/http://billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=187|archivedate=January 22, 2009|df=mdy-all}}</ref> and repeatedly stated the need for a viable, mainstream third political party. In addition, he criticized what he called the "[[Christian right]]", which he called "false Evangelicals", "false prophets",<ref>{{cite web|last=Laughlin|first=Tom|title=Three Fanatic Groups|url=http://www.billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=79|work=billyjack.com|accessdate=February 20, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051213200336/http://www.billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=79|archivedate=December 13, 2005}}</ref> and the "Christo-fascist movement."<ref name="Doug Basham"/> He released several videos and writings during the 2008 election.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tom Laughlin's YouTube Channel|url=https://www.youtube.com/user/TomLaughlin2007|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref>
===Psychology and counseling=== Although not a professionally trained psychologist, Laughlin had an interest in [[psychology]], having studied the subject independently.<ref name="Doug Basham"/> A 1975 profile of Laughlin in ''People'' magazine mentioned his deep interest in psychology and mentioned that he had a personal "dream secretary" to whom Laughlin told his recollections of his dreams. They were written down to be analyzed later.<ref name="people.com"/>
Laughlin lectured on [[Jung]]ian psychology at universities and colleges throughout the United States since the 1970s,<ref>{{cite news|title=Tom Laughlin at UVA|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=_p8cAAAAIBAJ&sjid=52gEAAAAIBAJ&pg=3623,2325716&dq=tom+laughlin&hl=en|work=The Cavalier Daily|date=November 2, 1978|accessdate=February 19, 2010}}</ref> including [[Yale University]] and [[Stanford University]]<ref name="unl.edu">{{cite news|title='Billy Jack' Continues Crusade Against Abuse and Violence|url=http://www.unl.edu/scarlet/v5n26/v5n26qa.html|work=The University of Nebraska-Lincoln Scarlet|date=October 6, 1995|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/19970617140544/http://www.unl.edu/scarlet/v5n26/v5n26qa.html|archivedate=June 17, 1997|accessdate=November 17, 2014}}</ref>
In 1995, because of his background in football and psychology, he was brought in to counsel [[University of Nebraska–Lincoln|University of Nebraska]] football player [[Lawrence Phillips]] after Phillips' suspension from [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|the team]]. He said of Phillips at the time, "He should not be rewarded by being allowed to play unless there is real substantive change. I don't mean surface change. But if he does change, then he's not only going to not batter this girl, he's not going to batter the girl he marries at 30 and 35. If he just pretends to change, of course he should not be allowed to play, but Lawrence has already been sanctioned in ways other batterers on this campus are not".<ref name="unl.edu"/>
Laughlin wrote several books on psychology including ''The Psychology of Cancer''; ''Jungian Psychology vol. 2: Jungian Theory and Therapy'', published in 1980; ''9 Indispendable Ingredients to Writing a Hit'' (1999), which details the psychology involved in the box office and hit filmmaking, and ''The Cancer Personality'' (1998), in which he posited his theories about cancer.<ref name="cancer">{{cite journal|last=Laughlin|first=Tom|title=The Psychology of Cancer|url=http://www.billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=184|journal=billyjack.com|accessdate=February 21, 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100721191439/http://www.billyjack.com/index.php?menuID=Page&pid=184|archivedate=July 21, 2010}}</ref>
One of his concerns was the issue of [[Domestic violence|domestic abuse]]. He became involved in this after witnessing a neighbor, a police officer, beating his wife.<ref name="Sacramento"/> He blamed [[O. J. Simpson murder case|the murder]] of [[Nicole Brown Simpson]] on domestic abuse, saying:<blockquote>O.J. Simpson was my neighbor up the street on Rockingham. He lived at 300 Rockingham Drive, I lived at 100 Rockingham. I've known O.J. forever. This is one of the sickest, sorriest days in our culture, that he was [found] not guilty... I've told him since 1985 he'd end up in jail... Eight times [Nicole] cried out and eight times, because it was O.J. and it was woman-battering, it was dismissed. But now, with the trivialization, people are afraid to call because they don't trust that the system will help them. The fact that he was found not guilty is going to make that 10 times worse.<ref name="unl.edu"/></blockquote>
==Personal life== Laughlin married [[Delores Taylor]] in 1954. They had three children: Frank, Teresa, and Christina. His daughter Teresa (known by the family as T.C.) is a fashion designer.<ref>{{cite web|title=T.C. Laughlin website|url=http://www.tclaughlin.com|work=tclaughlin.com|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> He derived at least two of his pseudonyms from his children: Frank Laughlin, his son's name and the name he used to direct ''The Trial of Billy Jack'' and ''The Master Gunfighter'', and T.C. Frank, which stood for Teresa Christina Frank.
In 2001, it was announced that Laughlin was suffering from a cancer of the tongue that was inoperable.<ref>{{cite news|title=Tom Laughlin Diagnosed with Cancer|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-47397405.html|journal=The Associated Press|date=October 8, 2001|accessdate=February 20, 2010}}</ref> His website claimed the cancer was in [[Cure#Remission|remission]]. His book, ''The Psychology of Cancer'', was about faith, attitude and other factors that might affect cancer.<ref name="cancer"/>
On November 20, 2007, he posted a video on YouTube explaining that poor health had caused him to leave his BillyJack.com website in a dormant state. The site was later revived. Laughlin suffered from [[Celiac disease]], an auto-immune disorder, and suffered a series of strokes.<ref>{{cite web|last=Waxman|first=Sharon|title=Billy Jack, the Super Sequel|url=http://www.thewrap.com/ind-column/687|work=The Wrap|date=March 2, 2008|accessdate=February 21, 2010}}</ref> In the video, he announced that he had his health issues under control, that he updated the website, and was planning a new Billy Jack film. However, that film was never made.{{Citation needed|date=December 2013}}
==Death== Laughlin died of complications from pneumonia on December 12, 2013 at Los Robles Hospital and Medical Center in [[Thousand Oaks, California]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/people/2013/12/15/billy-jack-star-tom-laughlin-dies/4033965|title='Billy Jack' star Tom Laughlin dies|work=[[USA Today]]|last1=Barrineau|first1=Trey|date=2013-12-15|accessdate=2013-12-15}}</ref>

'''Yom-Tov Lipmann ben Solomon Muhlhausen''' ([[Hebrew]]: '''יום טוב ליפמן מילהאוזן''') (Yom-Tov was his religious given name, Lipmann was his secular given name, one of the traditional Ashkenazic vernacular equivalents for Yom-Tov, while his last name represents a nickname indicating the origin of either him or his ancestors from the town of [[Mühlhausen]], in [[Thuringia]]) was a controversialist, [[Talmudist]], [[kabalist]] and [[philosopher]] of the 14th and 15th centuries (birth date unknown, died later than 1420). His religious and scholarly career and influence spanned the Jewish communities of [[Czech Jews|Bohemia]], [[Polish Jews|Poland]], [[Jews of Austria|Austria]] and various parts of [[German Jews|Germany]], and his dispute with the principles of Christianity left a lasting imprint on the relations between [[Christianity and Judaism]].
There is no comprehensive account of his life and career, which must be reconstructed from fragmentary references. According to [[Stephan Bodecker]], [[Bishop of Brandenburg]], who wrote a refutation of Lipmann's ''Niẓẓaḥon,'' Lipmann lived at [[Cracow]]. But [[Naphtali Hirsch Treves]], in the introduction to his ''Siddur,'' calls him "Lipmann Mülhausen of [[Prague]]", adding that he lived in the part of the town called "Wyschigrod." Manuscript No. 223 in the Halberstam collection contains a document issued at Prague in 1413 and signed by Lipmann Mülhausen, as ''[[Dayan (rabbinic judge)|dayyan]].''
==Attainments== It is seen from his ''Niẓẓaḥon'' that, besides his rabbinical studies, Lipmann occupied himself with the study of the [[Bible]], that he was acquainted with [[Karaite Judaism|Karaite]] literature, that he read the [[New Testament]], and that he knew [[Latin language|Latin]]. His authority in rabbinical matters is shown by his circular to the rabbis warning them against the use of any ''[[shofar]]'' not made of a ram's horn (comp. [[S.D. Luzzatto]] in ''Kerem Ḥemed,'' vii.56). There are also ''[[responsa]]'' addressed to him by [[Jacob ben Moses Mölln]] ([[A. Neubauer]], ''Cat. Bodl. Hebr. MSS.'' No. 907, 5), and [[Israel Isserlein]] mentions him (''Terumat ha-Deshen,'' No. 24) as one of five scholars who met at [[Erfurt]]. On 16 August 1399, Lipmann and many other Jews were thrown into prison at the instigation of a converted Jew named Peter, who accused them of insulting [[Christianity]] in their works. Lipmann was ordered to justify himself, but while he brilliantly refuted Peter's accusations, as a result of the charges seventy-seven Jews were [[martyred]] on 22 August 1400, and three more, by fire, on 11 September 1400. Of the accused Lipmann alone escaped death.
==Works== Lipmann was the author of: *''Sefer ha-Niẓẓaḥon,'' a refutation of [[Christianity]] and [[Karaism]] and a demonstration of the superiority of rabbinical Judaism. The work was the first to recount a Christian response to the ritual of [[Elijah's chair]].<ref>Revue des études juives: Volumes 143 à 144 Société des études juives (France), École pratique des hautes études (France). Section des sciences économiques et sociales, École des hautes études en sciences sociales - 1984 "The first author to recount a Christian response to the ritual of Elijah's Chair was Yom Tov Lipmann Muhlhausen (Prague, late fourteenth- mid-fifteenth century) in his Sefer Nizzahon (written between 1401-1405)"</ref> *''Zikron Sefer ha-Niẓẓaḥon'' a refutation of Christianity, an abstract in verse of the preceding work (pp. 107–117 in the ''Tela Ignea Satanæ'' of [[Johann Christoph Wagenseil|Wagenseil]], who supplied a [[Latin language|Latin]] translation and added a long refutation, Freiburg, 1681; [[A. Geiger]], in [[Bresslauer]]'s ''Deutscher Volkskalender,'' iii.48, declares Lipmann's authorship of this poem doubtful) *a commentary to the ''Shir ha-Yiẓud'' (Freiburg, 1560) *In [[Samson ben Eleazar]]'s ''Baruk she-Amar'' (Shklov, 1804) there is a [[kabalistic]] treatise on the [[Hebrew alphabet]], entitled ''Sefer Alfa Beta,'' the author of which is given as מהר"ל שלי"ו. [[S. Sachs]] and [[Steinschneider]] concluded that the author was Lipmann-Mülhausen. This work discusses: #the form of the letters #the reason for their form #the mystery of their composition, order, and numerical value, and #the kabalistic explanation of their form In this work the author frequently mentions a cabalistic work entitled ''Sefer ha-Eshkol'' and a commentary to the ''[[Sefer Yeẓirah]]'' *[[Menahem Ẓiyyoni]]'s ''Ẓefune Ẓiyyoni'' is ascribed, in a pamphlet quoted by [[Reuben ben Hoshke]] (''[[Yalḳuṭ Re'ubeni]],'' section "Naso"), to a certain R. Ṭabyomi, whom [[Steinschneider]] (''Cat. Bodl.'' col. 1411) identifies with Lipmann-Mülhausen. *Lipmann promises, in his ''Niẓẓaḥon'' (§197), a commentary to ''[[Pirḳe Abot]],'' but such a work is not extant. *Finally, it may be added that Manuscript 820 in [[David Oppenheim (rabbi)|Oppenheimer]]'s collection was supposed to be a Biblical commentary by the author of the ''Sefer ha-Niẓẓaḥon,'' but [[Dukes]] (''Orient, Lit.'' xi.299) declares that it is nothing else than the ''Niẓẓaḥon'' itself.
==Contents of the ''Niẓẓaḥon''== The Nizzahon was long inaccessible to Christian Hebraists, and a copy was only obtained in 1644 by a deceitful ruse, involving outright theft, by the professor of Hebrew at the [[University of Altdorf]], {{ill|Theodor Hackspan|de}}, who learning that a rabbi in [[Schnaittach]] possessed a copy, obtained an interview with him for a debate, and when the rabbi took down his copy to consult, had it snatched from his hands, to be then copied and printed. It is this copy which forms the ''editio princeps''.<ref>Ora Limor, Israel Jacob Yuval,'Scepticism and Conversion: Jews, Christians and Doubt in ''Sefer ha-Nizzahon'',' in Allison Coudert, Jeffrey S. Shoulson (eds.) [https://books.google.com/books?id=cDFCuuXd1DkC&pg=PA166''Hebraica Veritas?: Christian Hebraists and the Study of Judaism in Early Modern Europe,''] University of Pennsylvania Press, 2004 pp.159-179, pp.166.</ref>
Lipmann's reputation is dependent, mainly, upon his ''Niẓẓaḥon'' (ספר ניצחון). The book aimed to deal with the acute problems of conversion to Christianity among German Jews.<ref>Ora Limor, Israel Jacob Yuval,'Scepticism and Conversion: Jews, Christians and Doubt in ''Sefer ha-Nizzahon'',' in Allison Coudert, Jeffrey S. Shoulson (eds.) [''Hebraica Veritas?: Christian Hebraists and the Study of Judaism in Early Modern Europe,''] University of Pennsylvania Press, 2004 pp.159-179, pp.160-161.</ref> That a rabbi in the 15th century should occupy himself with the [[Latin language]] and the [[New Testament]] was certainly a rare thing. Lipmann was compelled to justify himself (§3) by referring to the saying of [[Rabbi Eliezer]], "Know what thou shalt answer to the heretic" (''[[Abot]]'' ii.14). The whole work consists of 354 paragraphs, the number of days in the lunar year, each paragraph, with the exception of the last eight, beginning with a passage of the [[Bible]], upon which the author founds his argument. Thus his arguments rest upon 346 passages taken from all the books of the [[Old Testament]]. The last eight paragraphs contain his dispute with the convert Peter. In the introduction, Lipmann says that he divided the work into seven parts to represent the seven days of the week. The part for the first day contains the arguments against [[Christians]]; that for the second day those against the [[Karaite Judaism|Karaite]] interpretation of the Bible; those for the remaining five days contain several interpretations of obscure Biblical passages that are likely to mislead students; the reasons for the commandments; arguments against [[atheists]]; arguments against the Karaites and their rejection of the [[Talmud]]; and an account of the sixteen things which comprehend the whole of [[Judaism]] and which, after being indicated in the [[Pentateuch]], are repeated in the [[Prophet]]s and [[Hagiographa]].
==Translations and refutations== Very characteristic is Lipmann's refutation of the assumed miraculous birth of [[Jesus]], as well as his demonstration of the falsity of the conclusions of the [[Christians]] who claim that the birth of Jesus was foretold by the [[Prophet]]s. He constantly quotes [[Maimonides]], [[Abraham ibn Ezra]], [[Naḥmanides]], [[Saadia]], [[Rashi]], [[Shemariah of Negropont]], and other ancient scholars. Lipmann must have written his ''Sefer ha-Niẓẓaḥon'' before 1410, for he expressed a hope that the [[Jewish Messiah|Messiah]] would arrive in that year (§335). It was first published by [[:de:Hackspanus|Hackspanus]] (Altdorf, 1644), who seized the manuscript from the rabbi of [[Schnaittach]] (Goldwurm 2001, p. 152). [[Johann Christoph Wagenseil]] published, at the end of his ''Sota'' (Altdorf-Nuremberg, 1674), corrections of Hackspan's edition under the title of ''Correctiones Lipmannianæ.''
Later, the ''Niẓẓaḥon'' was reprinted, with the addition of [[Ḳimḥi]]'s ''Vikkuaḥ,'' in Amsterdam (1709 and 1711) and Königsberg (1847). [[Sebald Snelle]] published the [[Hebrew]] text with a Latin translation and refutation of the paragraph (§8) denying the miraculous birth of Jesus (Altdorf, 1643), and at various dates he published Latin translations of the paragraphs directed against [[Christianity]]. A Latin translation of the whole work, with the exception of the passages taken from the [[Pentateuch]], was made by [[Johann Heinrich Blendinger]] (Altdorf, 1645). As will be readily understood, the work gave rise to many polemics and called forth replies from Christians. The first was [[Stephan Bodecker]], Bishop of Brandenburg, a younger contemporary of Lipmann, who wrote a refutation of the ''Niẓẓaḥon'' (comp. [[Wolf]], ''Bibl. Hebr.'' i.736). The following other refutations are published: [[Wilhelm Schickard]], ''Triumphator Vapulans sive Refutatio,'' etc. (Tübingen, 1629); [[Stephen Gerlow]], ''Disputatio Contra Lipmanni Nizzachon'' (Königsberg, 1647); [[Christian Schotan]], ''Anti-Lipmanniana'' (Franeker, 1659), giving also the Hebrew text of the ''Niẓẓaḥon.'' Informally, ''Anti-Lipmanniana'' came to be used also as an overall term for the entire corpus of Christian writings debating with and seeking to refute Lipman's arguments.
